item.title: Mark Drakeford set to become next first minister of Wales - Financial Times
item.description:
Mark Drakeford set to become next first minister of Wales  Financial Times

Mark Drakeford is set to become the next first minister of Wales after winning a leadership election for the Welsh Labour party. The 64-year-old Welsh finance secretary won 54 per cent of the vote, seeing off competition from rival assembly members Vaughan Gething and Eluned Morgan. As the result was announced at the Principality Stadium in Cardiff the new leader said he would continue the “radical socialist tradition” of Aneurin Bevan, Michael Foot and Rhodri Morgan. Mr Drakeford was special adviser to Mr Morgan during his tenure as first minister from 2000 to 2009. He backed Jeremy Corbyn...

item.title: Welsh finance minister considering bid to succeed Carwyn Jones - The Guardian
item.description:
Welsh finance minister considering bid to succeed Carwyn Jones  The Guardian

The Welsh finance secretary, Mark Drakeford, has emerged as an early frontrunner to succeed Carwyn Jones as Welsh first minister. Jones said on Saturday he would step down in the autumn, having experienced “the darkest of times”. He has been under intense pressure since the Labour AM Carl Sargeant killed himself four days after being sacked as a minister over harassment allegations. Drakeford is experienced and well-respected with Welsh Labour. He won plaudits in his former job as health minister by defending the Cardiff administration against Tory attacks on its record on running the NHS i...

item.title: Wales isolates Nicola Sturgeon over EU powers after Brexit - The Guardian
item.description:
Wales isolates Nicola Sturgeon over EU powers after Brexit  The Guardian

The Welsh government has left Nicola Sturgeon unexpectedly isolated after agreeing to sign a controversial deal with UK ministers over the sharing of EU powers after Brexit. Mark Drakeford, the Welsh finance secretary, said significant concessions the UK government had made in the last few days were enough to protect the Welsh assembly’s powers when Britain leaves the EU.
